A competitor showed his sympathy towards the victims of the Boston Marathon bombing during the Virgin London Marathon Chris Jackston/Getty Images
A large 'Thank You' poster, created by the St. James Armenian Church youth group was displayed on Mount Auburn Street in Watertown. Jared Wickerham/Getty Images
The Reverend Sean Connor held a parishioner's child during his sermon at a Mass at St. Ann Parish in Dorchester, where 8-year-old victim Martin Richard was mourned. Aram Boghosian for The Boston Globe
Jill Riemer, formerly of Newton, left, and Jessie Wohlgemuth, formerly of Belmont, listened to remarks about the Boston Marathon bombings during a run in New York City. Craig Ruttle/AP
An investigator and a dog walked across a deserted Boylston Street near the site of the Boston Marathon bombings. Brian Snyder/Reuters
Sisters Sarah Orr (left) and Heather Orr embraced at the memorial for the victims near the finish line. Michael Reynolds/EPA
Photos of the victims were placed on cloth-covered easels before Mass at the Cathedral of the Holy Cross. Pat Greenhouse/Globe Staff
A mourner displayed a program containing pictures of Krystle Campbell at her wake in Medford. Michael Reynolds/AP
A participant wore a singlet in tribute to victims from the Boston Marathon while taking part in a race at Central Park in New York. Eduardo Munoz/Reuters
Runners shoes and messages hang at a memorial to the victims of the bombings near the scene of the blasts on Boylston Street. Jim Bourg/Reuters
Men placed an American flag on their motorcycles outside the wake for Krystle Campbell in Medford. Bob Leonard/AP
Longtime Boston Athletic Association volunteer John Dalone of Stoneham waited to pay his respects to bombing victim Krystle Campbell at a funeral home in Medford. Dina Rudick/Globe Staff
Boston Police Commissioner Ed Davis, left, and Superintendents William Evans and Kevin Buckley carried the "gifts" to the altar during Mass at the Cathedral of the Holy Cross. Pat Greenhouse/Globe Staff
A mother held the hands of her son as they attended an interfaith worship service at a memorial on Boylston Street for the victims of the Boston Marathon bombings. Brian Snyder/Reuters
Rene Rancourt saluted the Watertown Police Honor Guard during the national anthem at the start of today's game between the Bruins and the Florida Panthers Barry Chin/Globe Staff
Runners observed a moment of silence before the start of the London Marathon. Luke MacGregor/Reuters
